articles.headline: Stalking a Weaker Wall Street
articles.snippet: After a year of tumult on Wall Street, overseas banks are coming in for cheap assets, solid talent and the possibility of raising their profiles on a global scale.
articles.abstract: After a year of tumult on Wall Street, overseas banks are coming in for cheap assets, solid talent and the possibility of raising their profiles on a global scale.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s great investment houses have never faced a serious foreign challenge in their own backyard. But as tectonic shifts reverberate through the banking industry, their overseas rivals are edging into some of the most lucrative corners of American finance.

articles.headline: Greenberg Defends Sale of A.I.G. Stock in Trust
articles.snippet: Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief of A.I.G., testified that he was entitled to remove $4.3 billion in the company’s stock under certain conditions.
articles.abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief of A.I.G., testified that he was entitled to remove $4.3 billion in the company’s stock under certain conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, testified on Tuesday that he always had the right to disband the insurance company’s retirement plan for top performers and to remove its assets under certain conditions.

articles.headline: Election at a Draw, Arizona Town Cuts a Deck
articles.snippet: The town of Cave Creek, Ariz., turned to a deck of cards to settle a local election.
articles.abstract: The town of Cave Creek, Ariz., turned to a deck of cards to settle a local election.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAVE CREEK, Ariz.  Arizona is a modern place, among the fastest-growing states and home to Phoenix, the nation’s fifth-largest city, with gleaming office towers and a just-opened light rail system.

articles.headline: MySpace Set to Lay Off 400 Workers
articles.snippet: MySpace was once the pre-eminent social networking site, but recently it has lost some luster to Facebook.
articles.abstract: MySpace was once the pre-eminent social networking site, but recently it has lost some luster to Facebook.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest step in Rupert Murdoch’s effort to turn around the fortunes of his digital businesses came Tuesday in the form of hefty layoffs at MySpace.

articles.headline: E-Mail Surveillance Renews Concerns in Congress
articles.snippet: Intercepts of Americans’ phone calls and e-mail messages are broader than previously acknowledged, officials said.
articles.abstract: Intercepts of Americans’ phone calls and e-mail messages are broader than previously acknowledged, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The National Security Agency is facing renewed scrutiny over the extent of its domestic surveillance program, with critics in Congress saying its recent intercepts of the private telephone calls and e-mail messages of Americans are broader than previously acknowledged, current and former officials said.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Kickin’ Down Madison Ave., Feelin’ Groovy
articles.snippet: Macy’s, General Mills, and Procter & Gamble are among companies with 2009 ad campaigns recalling aspects of the ’60s.
articles.abstract: Macy’s, General Mills, and Procter & Gamble are among companies with 2009 ad campaigns recalling aspects of the ’60s.
articles.lead_paragraph: The moon may not be in the seventh house. And only an astrologer knows for sure if Jupiter has aligned with Mars. But it seems like the dawning of the age of Aquarius on Madison Avenue, as images and sounds from the 1960s become increasingly popular in advertising.

articles.headline: Obama Sought a Range of Views on Finance Rules
articles.snippet: The administration’s proposal to overhaul financial rules, born of compromise, is not as bold as some had hoped.
articles.abstract: The administration’s proposal to overhaul financial rules, born of compromise, is not as bold as some had hoped.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s plan to reshape financial regulation, which he will unveil on Wednesday, is the product of weeks of meetings among government officials, financial experts, lawmakers, industry executives and lobbyists, many of whom were invited to help the White House draft the proposal.

articles.headline: U.S. to Extend Its Job Benefits to Gay Partners
articles.snippet: President Obama will extend benefits, but not full health insurance, to same-sex partners of federal employees.
articles.abstract: President Obama will extend benefits, but not full health insurance, to same-sex partners of federal employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama will sign a presidential memorandum on Wednesday to extend benefits to same-sex partners of federal employees, administration officials said Tuesday evening, but he will stop short of pledging full health insurance coverage.

articles.headline: Health Care Rationing Rhetoric Overlooks Reality
articles.snippet: The process of allocating resources already happens in health care. It just needs to be made more effective.
articles.abstract: The process of allocating resources already happens in health care. It just needs to be made more effective.

articles.headline: Protesters Defy Iranian Efforts to Cloak Unrest
articles.snippet: Protesters said that tens of thousands had massed in central Tehran again on Wednesday as Iran tried to block any coverage of opposition activities.
articles.abstract: Protesters said that tens of thousands had massed in central Tehran again on Wednesday as Iran tried to block any coverage of opposition activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  Iranians angry at the results of last week’s election pushed their protest forward on Wednesday, from tens of thousands who again flooded the streets here to six soccer players on the national team who wore opposition green wristbands at a World Cup qualifying game.
